questions.question: What kind of data structure does A* search use?
Is A* an informed or uninformed search algorithm?
In A* search, what is the role of the heuristic function?

answers.a: Estimates distance from the start node to the current node.
answers.b: Estimates the cost of the cheapest path from the current node to the goal node.
answers.c: Estimates distance from the start node to the goal node.
answers.d: Estimates the cost of the cheapest path from the start node to the goal node.

questions.question: In A* search, what does the f value represent?

answers.a: It represents the heuristic value of the current node.
answers.b: It represents the total estimated cost of the path from the start node to the goal node.
answers.c: It represents the cost of the cheapest path found from the start node to the current node.
answers.d: It represents the sum of the actual cost from the start node to the current node and the estimated cost from the current node to the goal node.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about A* search?

answers.c: It is never complete nor optimal.
answers.d: If the heuristic is consistent, it is complete and optimal.

questions.question: Which of the following scenarios would result in A* search performing poorly or even failing to find the optimal solution?

answers.a: When the graph has a high branching factor and the heuristic function is not informative
answers.b: When the heuristic function is consistent but not admissible
answers.c: When the heuristic function always returns a constant value
